titleStmt.title: Gibbon: History of the Rise and Fall of the Roman Empire

div.l: The Extent and Military Force of the Empire in the Age

p.l: IN the ſecond century of the Chriſtian Æra, the empire of Rome
comprehended the faireſt part of the earth, and the moſt ci-
vilized portion of mankind. The frontiers of that extenſive
monarchy were guarded by the ancient renown and diſciplined valour.
The gentle, but powerful influence of laws and manners had gra-
dually cemented the union of the provinces. Their peaceful in-
habitants enjoyed and abuſed the advantages of wealth and luxury.
The image of a free conſtitution was preſerved with decent reverence:
The Roman ſenate appeared to poſſeſs the ſovereign authority and
devolved on the emperors all the executive powers of government.
During a happy period of more than fourſcore years, the public
adminiſtration was conducted by the virtue and abilities of Nerva,
Trajan, Hadrian, and the two Antonines. It is the deſign of this
and of the two ſucceeding chapters, to deſcribe the proſperous con-
